“You are far too beautiful to just walk around here”

A/N:I’m so sorry this is late but I hope you’ll like it nevertheless

It’s very messy and not very authentic to the plot at some points too:/

Tomorrow was going to be a nightmare, you both knew that. He sighed into your neck, causing you to brush your back against him. “Stop that, darling”, he mumbled in a deep voice, already sleepy. “ Don’t think about tomorrow too much and just go to sleep. I’ll protect you no matter what, but - what can I say - you’re just too beautiful to walk around here.” You giggled into the darkness, already feeling a bit more relaxed at his cheesy remark.

The glances at the next morning were almost unbearable. Although Ghost was with you the entire time, you didn’t feel safe when Jon wasn’t accompanying you. And now even Ghost was gone, hunting probably. Sighing, you made your way to the well in the swords yard, gripping your bucket tightly. “Damn, if this isn’t a sight for sore eyes”, you heard someone say behind you and froze dead in your track. “Aye, she’s quite pretty, isn’t she?”, another voice chuckled and you heard laughter. “Stay away from me”, you demanded, your voice cracking at the end. “Now, now, no need to freak out, love”. They were circling you like prey with you held captive in their middle. You glanced around nervously, secretly praying for help. “Janos Slynt?”, you choked out and managed to chuckle a bit. “Never would’ve thought such a sack of fat could move that quickly, but it appears to me that when it comes to women, all men are on their feet, aren’t they?”, you said boldly. “Hush now girl and let us have a proper look at you”, another man demanded and grinned. You cringed in disgust and fear. When his hand brushed your thigh you closed your eyes when suddenly - all you heard were screams of horror and pain. You opened your eyes to see Ghost,

already leaving the men bloodied and dying. He had bitten their throats and was now shielding you in a protective way (gif). “Good boy”, you whispered, still shaking a bit from the incident. He immediately calmed, red eyes locking with yours as you both turned around.

“They tried what?”, Jon whispered angrily through gritted teeth when you quickly told him what happened. “I’ll take care of it”, he said sternly in his commander voice, already heading for the door. “Ghost is staying with you”, he added and returned to place a chaste kiss on your forehead. “Don’t worry, everything’s gonna work out. I won’t let them set us apart.” You only nodded and sent him a reassuring smile but couldn’t but notice a sting of unease in your stomach. Suddenly, the door sprung open and you flinched, half expecting wights. But it was just Olly, the boy rescued from the wildlings. Jon, still standing in front of you and shielding you with his body out of instinct, raised an eyebrow at him. “Sorry Lord Commander”, he gasped out with a red face. “They say your uncle’s back”. Wordlessly, Jon followed him out of the door quickly. You went to the window and looked outside into the snowy night. Ghost let out a low growl. “Ghost?”, you questioned, squatting down in front of him and stroked his fur. “Jon will be back any time soon”, you told him. Ghost only ran outside, now fully growling. You decided to follow him. “Jon?”, you called, growing a bit concerned. What could possibly make Ghost behave so aggressive? You hurried down the stairs and quickly spotted a group of shadows and ran over them with a relieved laugh. “Jon!” And there was Olly too - stabbing - a knife - into Jon’s - chest? You dropped to the ground and let out a blood-freezing scream. No. Not him. He looked at you for the last time before his eyes lost their light-for ever. You watched him die in disbelief, tears streaming down your face and not even feeling the hands carrying you back inside.

The next five years had made your heart cold. Shortly after his death, you had escaped with Ghost from Castle Black. Although you saw no sense in living, you saw none in dying either. You had hunted in the woods behind the wall. A year ago, you had to hide from wildlings who seemingly wanted to attack the castle. You didn’t care if they succeeded or not. You lived without any joy and spent your days distracting yourself from thinking too much about.. him. Until that one night.. You were skinning rabbits, Ghost was hunting and you had just decided to go farther north to eventually meet up with wildlings. Living on your own was though, and winter was coming, after all. Suddenly, you noticed a shadow standing near you. You gasped out in shock and grabbed your bow, aiming it at a - woman? “Do not fear me, Y/N”, she said gently, looking directly into my eyes. Her hair was fiery red and she wore a ruby necklace that had to be worth more than all your propertaties. You eyed her suspiciously, but slowly lowered the bow. “How do you know my name?”, you asked, your voice raw from not speaking so long. She smiled and began to walk around. “Azor Ahai is thinking about you all the time. In his sleep, in his dreams I can see you clear as the day. He misses you. He still loves you.” Loves me? Still loves me? “I don’t know who you’re talking about. I know no man of this name and neither do I have any one I once loved.” She sighed, piercing me with her red gaze. “You’ll know him under the name of a bastard. Jon Snow.” Tears welled up in your eyes and you gripped your bow tighter. “You’re lying. He died before my eyes, betrayed by his man and murdered as a traitor.” You wouldn’t cry. “I know, darling”, she said soothingly. “But I also saw him return from the dead, in fact” - she looked at her hands - “brought these hands him back.” You laughed. “Have you been drinking too much? Leave now.” “But it is true, he’s still Commander and yearning for you.” “How do I know you’re not lying?” “Do you know who Arya is?” Your breathing hitched. He used to talk about her so often. “She has arrived a few days ago, accompanied by a rather big woman and a little warrior boy.” Without saying anything, you stormed outside and ignored the smirk on the weirds woman face. It was too early have hope, you constantly told yourself. But if it WAS true..Ghost would pick on your tracks easily, you told yourself. And then you were there. The memories were overwhelming. Kissing Jon and inhaling his scent, riding and fighting and eating food from Three - Finger- Hobbs. The gate creaked open and you rode in nervously. And there he was. Taller and more serious than you remembered, but-alive. You gasped out when he stormed towards you. “Y/N”, he whispered and you felt a tingle when hearing his voice. With tears in your eyes, you nodded to allow him to put you down your horse. As his strong arms wrapped around you, he spun you and you screamed out in delight. “Don’t ever leave me again”, you whispered, bumping your forehead against his. He looked at you so desperately and happy and adoring you felt your heart melt again. And when he slowly lowered you to crush his mouth against yours, you couldn’t help but moan because you had craved this for so long. The kiss was a promise and you felt like you could trust in yourself again.

You would be happy again.

title: The Cost of Weaponizing Dragons For A Cause: Doran + Jon
body:
As some of you may know, I subscribe to the theory that dragons and the fire associated Azor Ahai reborn may not be effective in the war against the Others in the Long Night. People generally assume this means inverting the enemy from the Others to the dragons, and I’ve made that mistake too momentarily, but it seems more probable that both extreme fire and extreme ice can be harmful to Westeros. There is of course, the apocalyptic implications of the two extremes in Robert Frost’s poem Fire & Ice, that Martin admits to have influenced his title, but apart from that the author may have hinted the Others and Dany’s dragons being two apocalyptic threats to Westeros. 

[…] the two outlying ones — the things going on north of the Wall, and then there is Targaryen on the other continent with her dragons — are of course the ice and fire of the title, “A Song of Ice and Fire.” The central stuff — the stuff that’s happening in the middle, in King’s Landing, the capital of the seven kingdoms — is much more based on historical events, historical fiction. It’s loosely drawn from the Wars of the Roses and some of the other conflicts around the 100 Years’ War, although, of course, with a fantasy twist. You know, one of the dynamics I started with, there was the sense of people being so consumed by their petty struggles for power within the seven kingdoms, within King’s Landing that they’re blind to the much greater and more dangerous threats that are happening far away on the periphery of their kingdoms.

People tend to assume that in this equation, Dany is the political threat to Westeros corruption, but considering GRRM has equated dragons to nuclear power, a destructive force rather than a constructive one (”Dragons plant no trees”), this may as well embody the theme of Robert Frost’s Fire & Ice. Both can be equally destructive to human life. 

“Fire is a cruel way to die. Dalla died to give this child life, but you have nourished him, cherished him. You saved your own boy from the ice. Now save hers from the fire.” —Jon II, ADWD

Of course, a number of characters see the return of dragons as a boon with the interpretations of prophecies like Azor Ahai reborn, the Prince That Was Promised, and the presence of Others and the susceptibility of wights to fire and Jon wishing for dragons as weapons of defence at the Wall. That said, “Prophecy is a sword without a hilt”, and what may seem like a boon may actually be a nightmare. This is a device that has been used by authors like Tolkien in The Hobbit regarding the Esgaroth prophecy and Tad Williams in Memory, Sorrow, Thorn regarding the three magical swords from the title and the prophecy about Paris upon his birth from Trojan War cycle, all of whom Martin has admitted to draw inspiration from in his series. 

With all this serving as a framing context, lets get into the main topic of this post without much further ado. 

Given Dorne is the southern extreme of Westeros, I’ve often found despite its differences from the North, it shares many similarities and thus, many warnings too. Through the connected timeline of AFFC and ADWD, Doran and Jon make political decisions behind the back of the Lannisters and the Night’s Watch respectively risking treason or breaking a solemn oath in order to in fulfil their goals. It is striking how similar Doran’s plans to enlist Dany’s help through Quentyn and later to do a check up on f!Aegon through Arianne are with Jon sending Val to convince Tormund to bring his people to the Wall as well as using Mel and Dance to save f!Arya. But the connections go even further. 

Doran, House Martell and Vengeance for lost family

The history of House Martell and Dorne with the Targaryen dynasty and their loss of Elia and her children in Robert’s Rebellion due to House Lannister becomes increasingly important to Dany’s arc in ADWD. It is something she doesn’t completely realize when refusing Quentyn’s proposal as he doesn’t offer her the swords and ships she desires to conquer Westeros and it is also in part what leads to Quentyn’s death by Dany’s dragons. This political mishap shifts the political dynamics, of course, but more so it also shifts the perspective of Doran’s long coming revenge plot against the Lannisters with the help of Targaryens, which Meereenese Blot has dedicated a number of essays on. 

She narrowed her eyes. “What is our heart’s desire?”

“Vengeance.” His voice was soft, as if he were afraid that someone might be listening. “Justice.” Prince Doran pressed the onyx dragon into her palm with his swollen, gouty fingers, and whispered, “Fire and blood.” - Arianne II, AFFC

Doran’s plan to help Dany in her war in conquering back Westeros is fuelled by personal reasons of vengeance against Tywin. But he doesn’t seem to drop this plan even after Tywin is murdered. His desire for vengeance goes much deeper in trying to strip the Lannisters of their legacy, so Tywin couldn’t have left anything behind. At the same time, he doesn’t want too much destruction of human life to Dorne in this war knowing the impact of the Sack of King’s Landing that took Elia and her children’s lives. So instead of his own spears, he turns to dragons. 

“It is an easy thing for a prince to call the spears, but in the end the children pay the price. For their sake, the wise prince will wage no war without good cause, nor any war he cannot hope to win.” - Areo I, ADWD

He doesn’t send for Viserys despite the pact because he wanted him to get an army first that would ensure he was entering a war he could win. The Meereenese Blot talks a lot about the thematic criticism of vengeance as a motivating factor in Doran’s plan, which definitely fits with the larger themes of the series. Where does that vengeance stop? Ellaria voices this in front of Doran and the Sand Snakes. 

Obara bristled. “I never did and never shall.” She gave the skull a mocking kiss. “This is a start, I’ll grant.”

“A start?” said Ellaria Sand, incredulous. “Gods forbid. I would it were a finish. Tywin Lannister is dead. So are Robert Baratheon, Amory Lorch, and now Gregor Clegane, all those who had a hand in murdering Elia and her children. Even Joffrey, who was not yet born when Elia died. I saw the boy perish with mine own eyes, clawing at his throat as he tried to draw a breath. Who else is there to kill? Do Myrcella and Tommen need to die so the shades of Rhaenys and Aegon can be at rest? Where does it end?” - Areo I, ADWD

All of their perpetrators are gone. So is this cause just anymore? Doran and the Sand Snakes seem to have channelled their grief into this quest for revenge by killing everyone that wronged them and making them feel what loss truly feels like. But their perpetrators have died either without much of their hand in it or with additional loss of Oberyn. The spectrum of revenge and justice and the pitfalls of mistaking one for the others is a defining theme in Arya’s arc, and going by her journey and Lady Stoneheart’s the reader is pulled back to question if this revenge is more damaging to oneself and others. 

Ellaria’s questions can, of course, be stretched to Dany as well. Robert’s Rebellion may have been justified against Aerys but what happened in the Sack of King’s Landing and the attempts on Viserys and Dany’s lives were not. However, her belief in needing to go back to Westeros to “take back what is [hers]” for the sake of her family and the life on the run she was subjected to falls flat because Robert is dead; Tywin is dead; and while he never supported Robert’s and Tywin’s actions in going after mothers and children, Ned is dead too. And beyond that, there is only the fact that Robert’s Rebellion happened not just because Rhaegar abducted Lyanna, but because Aerys wrongfully executed Rickard and Brandon Stark, Jon Arryn’s nephew and heir, bannermen of Hoster Tully, and demanded Jon Arryn to deliver him both Ned and Robert. Beyond those war crimes that Tywin and Robert committed, the rebellion to overthrow the Targaryen dynasty was justified. So what is Dany coming to exact? Where has her impulsive vengeful conquering of Slaver’s Bay led her? She committed a number of war crimes too, no matter how just her cause. 

“A hundred years ago, Daenerys Targaryen came to Dorne to make a peace. Now another comes to make a war, and my brother will be her king and consort. King Quentyn. Why did that sound so silly? Almost as silly as Quentyn riding on a dragon.” - Arianne I, TWOW

The Water Gardens as a symbol of peace stand in stark contrast with Doran and Dany’s larger goals. Its history linked the Targaryens and the Martells in peaceful union and Daenerys I made people realise the beauty and fragility of children. Rhaegar put a dent in that peace when he passed by Elia and crowned Lyanna at the Tourney of Harrenhal and even entered into a war that costed Elia and her children their lives. But the final blow was delivered by Dany’s rejection of Quentyn’s proposal. She does it in part due to her duty to Meereen, but also because she wanted an army and ships, not a marriage alliance and one overlooked fact, because of Quaithe’s warning. 

His friends had lost sight of his true purpose here. The road leads through her, not to her. Daenerys is the means to the prize, not the prize itself. “ ’The dragon has three heads,’ she said to me. ’My marriage need not be the end of all your hopes,’ she said. ‘I know why you are here. For fire and blood.’ I have Targaryen blood in me, you know that. I can trace my lineage back—”

“Fuck your lineage,” said Gerris. “The dragons won’t care about your blood, except maybe how it tastes. You cannot tame a dragon with a history lesson. They’re monsters, not maesters - Daenerys VIII, ADWD

With this rejection two Targaryen siblings have slighted two Martells and caused their deaths inadvertently, where two Targaryen siblings of the past, Daeron II and Daenerys I sealed peace with Dorne by marrying into House Martell. Doran is too vengeful to let this slide, especially when he lost Oberyn so recently. Remember that Arianne’s one mistake causes the disfigurement of Myrcella’s face and Arys Oakheart’s death and Cersei is already planning for war.

"Only if we lost.”

“If? The word is when. Dorne is the least populous of the Seven Kingdoms. It pleased the Young Dragon to make all our armies larger when he wrote that book of his, so as to make his conquest that much more glorious, and it has pleased us to water the seed he planted and let our foes think us more powerful than we are, but a princess ought to know the truth. Valor is a poor substitute for numbers. Dorne cannot hope to win a war against the Iron Throne, not alone. And yet that may well be what you have given us.”  - The Princess in the Tower, AFFC

And Dany may have doomed herself by baiting Quentyn with the fact that he needn’t marry her and his journey to her for “fire and blood” may not be for nothing with the words “the dragon has three heads”. The fact that f!Aegon has landed in the Stormlands with an army, that Doran was waiting on also gives him more of a chance to go against Dany as the Dornish have fought away the dragons before. 

"Send a raven whenever you have news,” Prince Doran told her, “but report only what you know to be true. We are lost in fog here, besieged by rumors, falsehoods, and traveler’s tales. I dare not act until I know for a certainty what is happening.”

War is happening, though Arianne, and this time Dorne will not be spared. “Doom and death are coming,” Ellaria Sand had warned them, before she took her own leave from Prince Doran. - Arianne I, TWOW

Ultimately, if Doran’s own plans haven’t already backfired on him, choosing to enter this war for revenge over his lost family will only bring more tragedy to his House and perhaps, the very Water Gardens that he wants to protect. 

Apart from the motive that drives Doran’s plan that comes back to bite him, there is the method to consider. Is “Fire and Blood” a “cleaner method”? Quentyn, Hazzea and the destruction and loss of life at Astapor and the fighting pits of Meereen would say otherwise. 

“Frog would be glad to put Astapor behind him. The Red City was the closest thing to hell he ever hoped to know. The Yunkai'i had sealed the broken gates to keep the dead and dying inside the city, but the sights that he had seen riding down those red brick streets would haunt Quentyn Martell forever. A river choked with corpses. The priestess in her torn robes, impaled upon a stake and attended by a cloud of glistening green flies. Dying men staggering through the streets, bloody and befouled. Children fighting over half-cooked puppies. The last free king of Astapor, screaming naked in the pit as he was set on by a score of starving dogs. And fires, fires everywhere. He could close his eyes and see them still: flames whirling from brick pyramids larger than any castle he had ever seen, plumes of greasy smoke coiling upward like great black snakes.” - The Windblown, ADWD

That Dany wanted to stop slavery or at least punish slavers for their cruel treatment is admirable, but the method by which she does it destroys cities and shatters the economy without replacing it with something else. Thereby causing harm to the very people she wants to help and bringing the cost of more compromises to hold the peace when she does settle down to rule in Meereen. Her fragile peace is the cost of her impulsive approach, that she doesn’t start to question until after she storms through three cities. Having settled down, she is revealed as an ineffective ruler because of her temperament despite her intentions and this would be what she would be bringing to Westeros as well. 

[…] when he asked what the comet meant, she answered, “Blood and fire, boy, and nothing sweet.” - Bran I, ACOK

Jon, the Night’s Watch & Weapons of Defence

A number of people believe that even if Dany’s conquest may be misguided, her true goal is to go north of the Wall and fight the Others to protect the realm with the help of her dragons, particularly because of that first instance when Jon killed a wight in AGOT with a brand of fire. 

Truly, the gods had heard Jon’s prayer that night; the fire had caught in the dead man’s clothing and consumed him as if his flesh were candle wax and his bones old dry wood. Jon had only to close his eyes to see the thing staggering across the solar, crashing against the furniture and flailing at the flames. It was the face that haunted him most; surrounded by a nimbus of fire, hair blazing like straw, the dead flesh melting away and sloughing off its skull to reveal the gleam of bone beneath.Whatever demonic force moved Othor had been driven out by the flames; the twisted thing they had found in the ashes had been no more than cooked meat and charred bone. - Jon VIII, AGOT

And, of course, Jon’s thoughts when the free folk are about to invade the realm:

We should have twenty trebuchets, not two, and they should be mounted on sledges and turntables so we could move them. It was a futile thought. He might as well wish for another thousand men, and maybe a dragon or three. - Jon VIII, ADWD

Unlike Doran’s quest for revenge, Jon is trying to mobilise forces and would be willing to use dragons for the defence of the realm. But would it have different results merely because of a less negative intent? So far Jon has actively gone out to seek dragons, but Melisandre claims Stannis is a prophecised prince and he can “wake dragons out of stone”. 

Burning dead children had ceased to trouble Jon Snow; live ones were another matter. Two kings to wake the dragon. The father first and then the son, so both die kings. The words had been murmured by one of the queen’s men as Maester Aemon had cleaned his wounds. Jon had tried to dismiss them as his fever talking. Aemon had demurred. “There is power in a king’s blood,” the old maester had warned, “and better men than Stannis have done worse things than this.” The king can be harsh and unforgiving, aye, but a babe still on the breast? Only a monster would give a living child to the flames. - Jon I, ASOS

That said, he is skeptical about their entire PR because it involves human sacrifice, even children. But given we do have a character with dragons already and no sacrifice need be involved, he would be more open to seeking out her help. But would that still be a good thing? 

A point many forget is the Others aren’t the same as wights. 

“The wights had been slow clumsy things, but the Other was light as snow on the wind.” - Samwell I, ASOS

Wights are dead men are raised and controlled by the Others, and are a different race altogether. 

“Who goes there?“ A horse’s head emerged from the darkness. Sam felt a moment’s relief, until he saw the horse. Hoarfrost covered it like a sheen of frozen sweat, and a nest of stiff black entrails dragged from its open belly. On its back was a rider pale as ice. Sam made a whimpery sound deep in his throat. He was so scared he might have pissed himself all over again, but the cold was in him, a cold so savage that his bladder felt frozen solid. The Other slid gracefully from the saddle to stand upon the snow. Sword-slim it was, and milky white. Its armor rippled and shifted as it moved, and its feet did not break the crust of the new-fallen snow. - Samwell I, ASOS

[Othor’s] flesh was blanched white as milk, everywhere but his hands. His hands were black like Jafer’s. Blossoms of hard cracked blood decorated the mortal wounds that covered him like a rash, breast and groin and throat. Yet his eyes were still open. They stared up at the sky, blue as sapphires. - Jon VII, AGOT

“When he opened his mouth to scream, the wight jammed its black corpse fingers into Jon’s mouth. Gagging, he tried to shove it off, but the dead man was too heavy. Its hand forced itself farther down his throat, icy cold, choking him. Its face was against his own, filling the world. Frost covered its eyes, sparkling blue.” - Jon VII, AGOT

Unlike wights, they can snuff out flames. 

"Get away!” Grenn took a step, thrusting the torch out before him. “Away, or you burn.” He poked at it with the flames.

The Other’s sword gleamed with a faint blue glow. It moved toward Grenn, lightning quick, slashing. When the ice blue blade brushed the flames, a screech stabbed Sam’s ears sharp as a needle. The head of the torch tumbled sideways to vanish beneath a deep drift of snow, the fire snuffed out at once. - Samwell I, ASOS

So is fire really the solution against them? 

I. False Dawn

What does work on the Others, however, is dragonglass that the Jon finds at the Fist of First Men.

“And then he was stumbling forward, falling more than running, really, closing his eyes and shoving the dagger blindly out before him with both hands. He heard a crack, like the sound ice makes when it breaks beneath a man’s foot, and then a screech so shrill and sharp that he went staggering backward with his hands over his muffled ears, and fell hard on his arse. When he opened his eyes the Other’s armor was running down its legs in rivulets as pale blue blood hissed and steamed around the black dragonglass dagger in its throat. It reached down with two bone-white hands to pull out the knife, but where its fingers touched the obsidian they smoked. Sam rolled onto his side, eyes wide as the Other shrank and puddled, dissolving away. In twenty heartbeats its flesh was gone, swirling away in a fine white mist. Beneath were bones like milkglass, pale and shiny, and they were melting too. Finally only the dragonglass dagger remained, wreathed in steam as if it were alive and sweating. Grenn bent to scoop it up and flung it down again at once. “Mother, that’s cold.”

“Obsidian.” Sam struggled to his knees. “Dragonglass, they call it. Dragonglass. Dragon glass.”  - Samwell I, ASOS

The COTF, who are the species most associated with nature, were said to have employed it themselves instead of swords. Incidentally, dragonglass is called “frozen fire”, which in many ways seems to be a combination of ice and fire - not fire by itself.

“Dragonglass.” The red woman’s laugh was music. “Frozen fire, in the tongue of old Valyria. Small wonder it is anathema to these cold children of the Other.” - Samwell V, ASOS

@trinuviel has elaborated a lot more on this linking it to the COTF and the Last Hero here and how it could be that the legend of the forging of Lightbringer is the forging of any Valyrian steel sword because it is linked with magic, and how valyrian swords could be used as weapons as well. By comparing the North’s Long Night with legends around a similar phenomenon in parts of Essos like Yi-ti or Rhoyne that the answer may lie elsewhere and not in fire magic by itself. People also forget the last Long Night was won without dragons and rather with the help of COTF.

One could ask why would the author go through the ruse of framing ice and fire in opposition? Perhaps, because they’re both meant to be seen as threats and there’s a lot of blanks left unanswered and the R’hllor cult seems to give them more, whether correct or incorrect, than the COTF, Bloodraven or any Northerner. 

“My lord father used to tell me that a man must know his enemies. We understand little of the wights and less about the Others. We need to learn.“ - Jon III, ADWD 

It is R’hllorism that frames this dichotomy of one good side and one bad side. 

"The war?” asked Davos.

“The war,” she affirmed. “There are two, Onion Knight. Not seven, not one, not a hundred or a thousand. Two! Do you think I crossed half the world to put yet another vain king on yet another empty throne? The war has been waged since time began, and before it is done, all men must choose where they will stand. On one side is R'hllor, the Lord of Light, the Heart of Fire, the God of Flame and Shadow. Against him stands the Great Other whose name may not be spoken, the Lord of Darkness, the Soul of Ice, the God of Night and Terror. Ours is not a choice between Baratheon and Lannister, between Greyjoy and Stark. It is death we choose, or life. Darkness, or light.”  - Davos III, ASOS

This is a very black and white view of thinking and considering the tropes of conventional fantasy, readers assume Melisandre is wrong about who Azor Ahai reborn is, but not about what he/she is or what the war is about because we’ve seen the Others; they’re ice zombies and there’s close to nothing to sympathise there. Except isn’t the author’s goal to deal with “conflict in the human heart?” How do you deal with that if your greatest antagonist is just non-thinking, out to kill the living? People would faster believe they’re controlled by Bloodraven, which they may or may not be, and he’s the actual enemy. But is that enough? 

The talk of Daenerys and her dragons hasn’t completely reached the Wall as Aemon and Sam find out about her in Braavos, but before dying Aemon held Sam to oath to research all he can about the prince that was promised prophecy in order to help Daenerys. It won’t be long before Sam writes to Jon about her or more news gets to Jon at the Wall after his resurrection and upon her arrival to Dragonstone, because of the dragonglass also present there he would have double the reason to approach her. However, Jon knows about Hardhome and once again it serves as a warning. 

“Hardhome had been halfway toward becoming a town, the only true town north of the Wall, until the night six hundred years ago when hell had swallowed it. Its people had been carried off into slavery or slaughtered for meat, depending on which version of the tale you believed, their homes and halls consumed in a conflagration that burned so hot that watchers on the Wall far to the south had thought the sun was rising in the north. Afterward ashes rained down on haunted forest and Shivering Sea alike for almost half a year. Traders reported finding only nightmarish devastation where Hardhome had stood, a landscape of charred trees and burned bones, waters choked with swollen corpses, blood-chilling shrieks echoing from the cave mouths that pocked the great cliff that loomed above the settlement.” - Jon VIII, ADWD

Similar wording is used for the Dragonpit burning atop Rhaenys’ Hill during the Dance of Dragons. 

“[The] queen’s own dragon remained alive and free … and as the burned and bloody survivors of the carnage in the pit came stumbling from the smoking ruins, Syrax descended upon them from above. A thousand shrieks and shouts echoed across the city, mingling with the dragon’s roar. Atop the Hill of Rhaenys, the Dragonpit wore a crown of yellow fire, burning so bright it seemed as if the sun was rising. Even the queen trembled as she watched, the tears glistening on her cheeks. Many of the queen’s companions on the rooftop fled, fearing that the fires would soon engulf the entire city, even the Red Keep atop Aegon’s High Hill. Others took themselves to the castle sept to pray for deliverance.” - Princess and the Queen

A false dawn, again. The state of Hardhome sounds a bit like that of Valyria after the Doom and Asshai, which is struck by magical pollution. It was attacked once by fire and in ADWD it was attacked once by ice. Both had devastating effects. 

II. Dragons Plant No Trees

Regarding the credibility of the notion of “ice = death” and “fire = life”, much of Melisandre and Davos’s arguments on darkness and light shows how the lines blur and one becomes the other. Darkness is shown to cloak and protect and this is most shown through Bran’s chapters as he hides in the crypts and in the cities of the COTF below the ground, even if Bloodraven might be taking advantage of Bran’s innocence. Not to mention there are Saladhor Saan’s words of warning. 

“Be glad that it is just a burnt sword that His Grace pulled from that fire. Too much light can hurt the eyes, my friend, and fire burns.“ - Davos I, ACOK

Fire in limited amount might help but the idea that dragons as weapons of mass destruction could save humankind seems unlikely to me because they are “fire made flesh” to the Others’ “ice made flesh”. If ice can freeze, too much fire can burn. We also get characters like Beric and Lady Stoneheart resurrected through R’hllor’s fire magic and that doesn’t seem like a good thing either. Beric is drained and loses his memories each time he gets back, and Catelyn has lost her humanity. Both of them driven by their last goal before dying, and not much else. Is that truly living? GRRM even calls them “wights animated by fire”. 

II.A: Deconstruction of the fantasy hero

Then of course, one is left to wonder if fire wights are not good, what does it say about Jon since Martin also claimed that bookwise, Beric is foreshadowing for Jon being drained after coming back from death.

And Jon Snow, too, is drained by the experience of coming back from the dead on the show.
GRRM: Right. And poor Beric Dondarrion, who was set up as the foreshadowing of all this, every time he’s a little less Beric. His memories are fading, he’s got all these scars, he’s becoming more and more physically hideous, because he’s not a living human being anymore. His heart isn’t beating, his blood isn’t flowing in his veins, he’s a wight, but a wight animated by fire instead of by ice, now we’re getting back to the whole fire and ice thing.

Many people assume this means Jon will come back as a fire wight himself. But he does warg into Ghost when he dies, so in a sense his soul is preserved by COTF magic - more than Beric’s at least. @occupyvenus has written her own meta on why Jon won’t come back as a fire wight because of a mixture of magic used to resurrect him (COTF, fire, blood and shadowbinding) - even if some may not be intended by Melisandre. This would prevent Jon from becoming a complete slave to one element, driven by one thought. He still would be drained, and will come back greyer, darker (as Martin has suggested in comparison to his issues with Gandalf) and probably more wolfish from his time in Ghost after having tried to reject his wolf side; probably even his memories will start to fade.

“I do think that if you’re bringing a character back, that a character has gone through death, that’s a transformative experience. […] My characters who come back from death are worse for wear. In some ways, they’re not even the same characters anymore. The body may be moving, but some aspect of the spirit is changed or transformed, and they’ve lost something. - GRRM, Bullseye Interview

“So all that time I thought Gandalf was dead, and now he’s back and now he’s Gandalf the White. And, ehh, he’s more or less the same as always, except he’s more powerful. It always felt a little bit like a cheat to me. And as I got older and considered it more, it also seemed to me that death doesn’t make you more powerful. That’s, in some ways, me talking to Tolkien in the dialogue, saying, ’Yeah, if someone comes back from being dead, especially if they suffer a violent, traumatic death, they’re not going to come back as nice as ever.’ That’s what I was trying to do, and am still trying to do, with the Lady Stoneheart character.” - GRRM, TIME interview

I have often wondered why he made Jon go through such a plot if he hates resurrection plots so much (a problem he had with Wonderman when he was younger as well, despite being inspired by his complexity). I dubbed this problem the “Resurrection Problem” and while thinking on it, I realised Jon wasn’t supposed to come back “improved” as a prophecised hero, but lesser than he was.

“Death is a pretty serious business. I remember when I was on a TV show in 80s ‘Beauty and the Beast” and Linda Hamilton was the star and after two seasons she left. It was more dramatic to write her out and bring on a new Beauty [then to end the show]. The network supported us in killing her but wanted us to get past it very quickly. We had a big fight with them about it. The next episode was her funeral and the next 12 episodes was the search for her murderer and Beast’s vengeance but the network was like ‘people don’t want to be sad.” Kill her and never mention her again. Death should hurt just like it does when death happens to us in real life. It’s a gut-wrenching event we can’t easily shrug it aside.

I want my readers to feel emotions. Fiction is about emotion. I want you guys to read my books and laugh and cry and be scared and if the character is in jeopardy I want you to be afraid to turn the next page. And not all the emotions are good ones.” - GRRM, UPROXX

I think the show might’ve just not grasped Martin’s complexity here. He wanted Jon’s death to shake him, traumatise him instead of just making him go into deep sleep and getting up. What he might’ve been going for emotionally was Buffy’s resurrection in BtVS that leaves her traumatised, apathetic and resentful towards her friends for pulling her out of heaven to return to the job of trying to save the world. From a hero she turns into an anti hero, and Jon was already getting there from ASOS to ADWD. Buffy’s resurrection was one that was done well because it didn’t brush away the seriousness of death. But like his time on “Beauty and the Beast”, I guess D&D didn’t want to really spend the remaining episodes/seasons on Jon’s emotional transformation of that complexity, as they skipped it with Beric and skipped Lady Stoneheart altogether. What I do think they kept to is that Jon would be so scarred that he would not want to be brought back a second time, unlike Beric and this might be possible because the mixture of magic that bring him back after his time in Ghost don’t make him fixate on one goal. 

One could then ask what was the Watsonian purpose of Jon being resurrected if he isn’t some prophecised hero or messiah? I think that so much fantasy fiction writes Messianic characters resurrections “for a reason” that Jon not having that role, and rather affecting the politics more in a way unrelated to it would be subversive. I keep revisiting this topic of Jon’s resurrection because I find that it deserves looking at more closely because as @thewesterwoman​ has written, Jon is the only candidate, who can answer “What was Aragorn’s tax policy?” and this isn’t based on character preference, but looking at which character is best trained in daily governance and is trying to bring about change through policy work. Of course, he can’t do it alone and he does need other people’s skills, insights and connections and that’s part of why he died after isolating himself from his friends as Lord Commander and it goes back to the “the lone wolf dies, but the pack survives”. It stands on the notion that a government shouldn’t be built on the concept of an ideal ruler, but a collaborative government that doesn’t cover for the king, but serves the realm. 

One might also ask who would save the day then if not Jon or Dany and if Azor Ahai reborn/PTWP is a destroyer rather than a saviour? Somehow everyone forgets Bran and how he’s actually Dany’s equivalent in his potency of magic and visions and he is associated with earth magic and trees. 

"The godswood.” Meera Reed ran after the direwolf, her shield and frog spear to hand. The rest of them trailed after, threading their way through smoke and fallen stones. The air was sweeter under the trees. A few pines along the edge of the wood had been scorched, but deeper in the damp soil and green wood had defeated the flames. “There is a power in living wood,” said Jojen Reed, almost as if he knew what Bran was thinking, “a power strong as fire.” - Bran VII, ACOK

The Lost Hero sought out the COTF from their secret cities and Bran the Builder helped build the Wall with the COTF’s help, so perhaps the answer lies with a more “living” element of nature as they are put in opposition to ice and fire. If the Others are related to death, so is Dany called “Daughter of Death” in the HOTU, and it does become a trend in hindsight that she leaves a trail of death and instability behind no matter where she goes. In that sense, earth magic that is not a pure magic unlike the Others and Valyrian dragons because the land is a mixture of a number of elements. 

“Why can’t it be both?” Meera reached up to pinch his nose. “Because they’re different,” he insisted. “Like night and day, or ice and fire.” “If ice can burn,” said Jojen in his solemn voice, “then love and hate can mate. Mountain or marsh, it makes no matter. The land is one." - Bran II, ASOS

trinuviel has elaborated on this synthesis being a sign of impurity, which is positive in Martin’s world that approaches purity negatively, like the Targaryens marrying their siblings to “keep the bloodline pure”. If the books follow the show about the COTF creating the Others as weapons against the First Men, even then the fact that they are able to separate themselves from the Others, unlike the Valyrians attachment to dragons, shows hope.  

II.B: A Dragon is not a Slave

If Jon’s role is more political so would his employment of Dany’s help with dragons. Ironically, within Jon’s chapters itself Tycho Nestoris from the Iron Bank gives Jon a warning when he talks about dragons flippantly.

"Salladhor Saan?”

“The Lysene pirate? Some say he has returned to his old haunts, this is so. And Lord Redwyne’s war fleet creeps through the Broken Arm as well. On its way home, no doubt. But these men and their ships are well-known to us. No, these other sails … from farther east, perhaps … one hears queer talk of dragons.”

“Would that we had one here. A dragon might warm things up a bit.”

“My lord jests. You will forgive me if I do not laugh. We Braavosi are descended from those who fled Valyria and the wroth of its dragonlords. We do not jape of dragons.” - Jon IX, ADWD

Jon doesn’t take this warning very seriously perhaps because he doesn’t expect to run into a dragon any time soon or because the Targaryen dynasty to his mind is a thing of the past and only a topic of songs in Westeros. But when Dany does land in Westeros, he might be more keen and when he does approach Dany for her dragons, army and dragonglass on Dragonstone (which Stannis has already lost to the Tyrells and he may perish in the North), he would be approaching her for utilitarian reasons. Perhaps, he even has to act as Quentyn’s foil and do what he cannot and even what f!Aegon cannot, thinking he has more limitations because he doesn’t know his own parentage - making his goal in the end prove futile. Like Doran or perhaps more than him considering he would be meeting Dany during her campaign of conquest, he would probably know there might be a risk. But he’d be willing to take it and try to minimise collateral damage. But the question again is, can dragons truly be controlled? Can nuclear power truly be controlled, if used for selfless reasons?

Dragons are the nuclear deterrent, and only Daenerys has them, which in some ways makes her the most powerful person in the world,” Martin said in 2011. “But is that sufficient? These are the kind of issues I’m trying to explore. The United States right now has the ability to destroy the world with our nuclear arsenal, but that doesn’t mean we can achieve specific geopolitical goals. Power is more subtle than that. You can have the power to destroy, but it doesn’t give you the power to reform, or improve, or build. - GRRM

In this event, Jon’s first experience with Othor’s wight comes to mind. @occupyvenus often says, “Jon tries to use fire to fight ice and burns his fingers” as foreshadowing for the future. He didn’t come out of that experience untouched as his sword hand got burnt, and that was just a make shift torch he made on instinct. The impact of seeking out Dany and her dragons and trying to control her impulses will only work to a certain extent, until like Doran, what he is trying to protect burns too. Essentially, trying to fight the Others, who represent climate change, with dragons, is like trying to fight them with an atom bomb. It’s playing with fire because not only are dragons unpredictable, Dany is unpredictable. 

The theme of home has a huge significance in the story for a number of characters, who are seeking a place to belong. Where Dany is concerned, because she has lived her life on the run and because she has internalised Viserys’ belief that the only place she can feel at home is Westeros in King’s Landing and Dragonstone, that becomes her tragedy as she fails to set up roots anywhere she settles, as she looks West. Dany has no roots and therefore, she uproots people wherever she goes, intentionally or not. Theon seems to share this trend initially as he struggles between wanting to hate the Starks for uprooting him from Pyke and his family as a Greyjoy, but he also loves them and wants to be part of them, but cannot be as a ward. As Martin has said, although in a similar situation as Theon as part of the Starks and yet not part of it, Jon avoids becoming like him and acting on his negative feelings. Sansa, Arya and Bran, who despite their varying reasons of feeling out of place in Winterfell, find themselves longing to go back to it as they realise they had more than they realised. Moreover, the Starks’ connection to Winterfell is through family and it serves as a tether to hold onto humanity and their identity. For Dany, after losing all her family, she grasps onto her dragon eggs and walks into the funeral pyre to hatch them, and when they do, she considers them her children. That unhealthy attachment to something so disastrous to human life is what ultimately could be the final straw in driving Dany to put them before humanity, as this starts from AGOT itself when she asks for her dragon eggs, rather than Rhaego in between her fevered dreams. That is foreboding in hindsight.     

Under the influence of a dragon rider, dragons can affect far larger masses than on their own. Whether wanting to use it on the offensive, like Doran, or on the defensive, like Jon, a dragon still cannot be tamed.  The North will not be spared as much as he’d like, as Dorne will not be. There is even foreshadowing for Dany’s dragons burning Winterfell when Summer looks up in the sky during the Sack of Winterfell and considering the line “Dragons plant no trees”, I wouldn’t be surprised if Dany’s dragons try to burn Winterfell’s heart tree to drive the point home. Perhaps because living wood has “power as strong as fire”, the heart tree and part of the godswood may be spared, but a large part of Winterfell may not. 

Interviewer: The number one question people ask me about the series is whether I think everyone will lose—whether it will end in some horrible apocalypse. I know you can’t speak to that specifically, but as a revisionist of epic fantasy— 

I haven’t written the ending yet, so I don’t know, but no. That’s certainly not my intent. I’ve said before that the tone of the ending that I’m going for is bittersweet. I mean, it’s no secret that Tolkien has been a huge influence on me, and I love the way he ended Lord of the Rings. It ends with victory, but it’s a bittersweet victory. Frodo is never whole again, and he goes away to the Undying Lands, and the other people live their lives. And the scouring of the Shire—brilliant piece of work, which I didn’t understand when I was 13 years old: “Why is this here? The story’s over?” But every time I read it I understand the brilliance of that segment more and more. All I can say is that’s the kind of tone I will be aiming for. - GRRM 

The author has voiced his love for the Scouring of Shire in LOTR a number of times, and said that is the kind of end he is hoping for. The world isn’t destroyed, but the Hobbits’ world is. Winterfell is the most Shire-like place in Westeros, and it has already had the Library Tower burning as part of the attack on Bran, and the Sack of Winterfell. Keeping with the pattern of threes in significant locations, it may have to burn once more. It may be that like the Hobbits, the Starks may save the realm, but may not be able to save their home. There would be a kind of symmetry to the Water Gardens and the Glass Gardens being destroyed indirectly because Doran and Jon weaponise dragons for a cause. 

This might be Jon’s tragedy as he tries to be the hero (even when he’s too tired to be), tries to protect his homeland and the realm, making sacrifices and playing the game, he still fails because he doesn’t have enough context and overestimates his ability to keep Dany in check. It may be that despite his resurrection, he isn’t some promised hero nor is Dany for hatching her dragons after walking into a funeral pyre. Death doesn’t make Jon more powerful, but rather weaker and less of a hero - despite his attempts. 

That said, the ending is meant to be bittersweet it may be upon the Starks and their allies to rebuild Westeros from its shambles. Perhaps, the irony would be that Jon, who is a hybrid of a dragon and a wolf, would in fact plant trees in contrast to Dany because he has roots connecting him to people and the land, even after it may be destroyed.

People generally assume this means inverting the enemy from the Others to the dragons, and I’ve made that mistake too momentarily, but it seems more probable that both extreme fire and extreme ice can be harmful to Westeros. There is of course, the apocalyptic implications of the two extremes in Robert Frost’s poem Fire & Ice, that Martin admits to have influenced his title, but apart from that the author may have hinted the Others and Dany’s dragons being two apocalyptic threats to Westeros. 

[…] the two outlying ones — the things going on north of the Wall, and then there is Targaryen on the other continent with her dragons — are of course the ice and fire of the title, “A Song of Ice and Fire.” The central stuff — the stuff that’s happening in the middle, in King’s Landing, the capital of the seven kingdoms — is much more based on historical events, historical fiction. It’s loosely drawn from the Wars of the Roses and some of the other conflicts around the 100 Years’ War, although, of course, with a fantasy twist. You know, one of the dynamics I started with, there was the sense of people being so consumed by their petty struggles for power within the seven kingdoms, within King’s Landing that they’re blind to the much greater and more dangerous threats that are happening far away on the periphery of their kingdoms.

People tend to assume that in this equation, Dany is the political threat to Westeros corruption, but considering GRRM has equated dragons to nuclear power, a destructive force rather than a constructive one (”Dragons plant no trees”), this may as well embody the theme of Robert Frost’s Fire & Ice. Both can be equally destructive to human life. 

“Fire is a cruel way to die. Dalla died to give this child life, but you have nourished him, cherished him. You saved your own boy from the ice. Now save hers from the fire.” —Jon II, ADWD

Of course, a number of characters see the return of dragons as a boon with the interpretations of prophecies like Azor Ahai reborn, the Prince That Was Promised, and the presence of Others and the susceptibility of wights to fire and Jon wishing for dragons as weapons of defence at the Wall. With all this serving as a framing context, lets get into the main topic of this post without much further ado.

Given Dorne is the southern extreme of Westeros, I’ve often found despite its differences from the North, it shares many similarities and thus, many warnings too. Through the connected timeline of AFFC and ADWD, Doran and Jon make political decisions behind the back of the Lannisters and the Night’s Watch respectively risking treason or breaking a solemn oath in order to in fulfil their goals. It is striking how similar Doran’s plans to enlist Dany’s help through Quentyn and later to do a check up on f!Aegon through Arianne are with Jon sending Val to convince Tormund to bring his people to the Wall as well as using Mel and Dance to save f!Arya. But the connections go even further. 

Doran, House Martell and Vengeance for lost family

The history of House Martell and Dorne with the Targaryen dynasty and their loss of Elia and her children in Robert’s Rebellion due to House Lannister becomes increasingly important to Dany’s arc in ADWD. It is something she doesn’t completely realize when refusing Quentyn’s proposal as he doesn’t offer her the swords and ships she desires to conquer Westeros and it is also in part what leads to Quentyn’s death by Dany’s dragons. This political mishap shifts the political dynamics, of course, but more so it also shifts the perspective of Doran’s long coming revenge plot against the Lannisters with the help of Targaryens, which Meereenese Blot has dedicated a number of essays on. 

She narrowed her eyes. “What is our heart’s desire?”

“Vengeance.” His voice was soft, as if he were afraid that someone might be listening. “Justice.” Prince Doran pressed the onyx dragon into her palm with his swollen, gouty fingers, and whispered, “Fire and blood.” - Arianne II, AFFC

Doran’s plan to help Dany in her war in conquering back Westeros is fuelled by personal reasons of vengeance against Tywin. But he doesn’t seem to drop this plan even after Tywin is murdered. His desire for vengeance goes much deeper in trying to strip the Lannisters of their legacy, so Tywin couldn’t have left anything behind. At the same time, he doesn’t want too much destruction of human life to Dorne in this war knowing the impact of the Sack of King’s Landing that took Elia and her children’s lives. So instead of his own spears, he turns to dragons. 

“It is an easy thing for a prince to call the spears, but in the end the children pay the price. For their sake, the wise prince will wage no war without good cause, nor any war he cannot hope to win.” - Areo I, ADWD

He doesn’t send for Viserys despite the pact because he wanted him to get an army first that would ensure he was entering a war he could win. The Meereenese Blot talks a lot about the thematic criticism of vengeance as a motivating factor in Doran’s plan, which definitely fits with the larger themes of the series. Where does that vengeance stop? Ellaria voices this in front of Doran and the Sand Snakes. 

Obara bristled. “I never did and never shall.” She gave the skull a mocking kiss. “This is a start, I’ll grant.”

“A start?” said Ellaria Sand, incredulous. “Gods forbid. I would it were a finish. Tywin Lannister is dead. So are Robert Baratheon, Amory Lorch, and now Gregor Clegane, all those who had a hand in murdering Elia and her children. Even Joffrey, who was not yet born when Elia died. I saw the boy perish with mine own eyes, clawing at his throat as he tried to draw a breath. Who else is there to kill? Do Myrcella and Tommen need to die so the shades of Rhaenys and Aegon can be at rest? Where does it end?” - Areo I, ADWD

All of their perpetrators are gone. So is this cause just anymore? Doran and the Sand Snakes seem to have channelled their grief into this quest for revenge by killing everyone that wronged them and making them feel what loss truly feels like. But their perpetrators have died either without much of their hand in it or with additional loss of Oberyn. The spectrum of revenge and justice and the pitfalls of mistaking one for the others is a defining theme in Arya’s arc, and going by her journey and Lady Stoneheart’s the reader is pulled back to question if this revenge is more damaging to oneself and others. 

Ellaria’s questions can, of course, be stretched to Dany as well. Robert’s Rebellion may have been justified against Aerys but what happened in the Sack of King’s Landing and the attempts on Viserys and Dany’s lives were not. However, her belief in needing to go back to Westeros to “take back what is [hers]” for the sake of her family and the life on the run she was subjected to falls flat because Robert is dead; Tywin is dead; and while he never supported Robert’s and Tywin’s actions in going after mothers and children, Ned is dead too. And beyond that, there is only the fact that Robert’s Rebellion happened not just because Rhaegar abducted Lyanna, but because Aerys wrongfully executed Rickard and Brandon Stark, Jon Arryn’s nephew and heir, bannermen of Hoster Tully, and demanded Jon Arryn to deliver him both Ned and Robert. Beyond those war crimes that Tywin and Robert committed, the rebellion to overthrow the Targaryen dynasty was justified. So what is Dany coming to exact? Where has her impulsive vengeful conquering of Slaver’s Bay led her? She committed a number of war crimes too, no matter how just her cause. 

“A hundred years ago, Daenerys Targaryen came to Dorne to make a peace. Now another comes to make a war, and my brother will be her king and consort. King Quentyn. Why did that sound so silly? Almost as silly as Quentyn riding on a dragon.” - Arianne I, TWOW

The Water Gardens as a symbol of peace stand in stark contrast with Doran and Dany’s larger goals. Its history linked the Targaryens and the Martells in peaceful union and Daenerys I made people realise the beauty and fragility of children. Rhaegar put a dent in that peace when he passed by Elia and crowned Lyanna at the Tourney of Harrenhal and even entered into a war that costed Elia and her children their lives. But the final blow was delivered by Dany’s rejection of Quentyn’s proposal. She does it in part due to her duty to Meereen, but also because she wanted an army and ships, not a marriage alliance and one overlooked fact, because of Quaithe’s warning. 

His friends had lost sight of his true purpose here. The road leads through her, not to her. Daenerys is the means to the prize, not the prize itself. “ ’The dragon has three heads,’ she said to me. ’My marriage need not be the end of all your hopes,’ she said. ‘I know why you are here. For fire and blood.’ I have Targaryen blood in me, you know that. I can trace my lineage back—”

“Fuck your lineage,” said Gerris. “The dragons won’t care about your blood, except maybe how it tastes. You cannot tame a dragon with a history lesson. They’re monsters, not maesters - Daenerys VIII, ADWD

With this rejection two Targaryen siblings have slighted two Martells and caused their deaths inadvertently, where two Targaryen siblings of the past, Daeron II and Daenerys I sealed peace with Dorne by marrying into House Martell. Doran is too vengeful to let this slide, especially when he lost Oberyn so recently. Remember that Arianne’s one mistake causes the disfigurement of Myrcella’s face and Arys Oakheart’s death and Cersei is already planning for war.

"Only if we lost.”

Valor is a poor substitute for numbers. Dorne cannot hope to win a war against the Iron Throne, not alone. And yet that may well be what you have given us.”  - The Princess in the Tower, AFFC

And Dany may have doomed herself by baiting Quentyn with the fact that he needn’t marry her and his journey to her for “fire and blood” may not be for nothing with the words “the dragon has three heads”. The fact that f!Aegon has landed in the Stormlands with an army, that Doran was waiting on also gives him more of a chance to go against Dany as the Dornish have fought away the dragons before.
